sn47.5:4.3: “Rightly speaking, mendicants, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unwholesome’.
sn47.5:4.4: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unwholesome.
sn47.5:4.7: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
sn47.5:4.8: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unwholesome’.
sn47.5:4.9: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unwholesome.
sn47.5:5.1: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the wholesome’.
sn47.5:5.2: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the wholesome.
sn47.5:5.5: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.5:5.6: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.5:5.7: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind …
sn47.5:5.8: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.5:5.9: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the wholesome’.
sn47.5:5.10: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the wholesome.”
